head.supplied: Copy ¶ Melbourne Botan. Garden 19/10/69 ¶ Sir ¶ ¶ In compliance with your request, expressed this day, I have the honor of submitting to you a tabulated schedule shewing the number and names of the e...

div.p: To James McKean
T69/10638, unit 432, VPRS 3991/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

Is the original of this letter in the Board of Land and Works records?
Copy
Melbourne Botan. Garden 19/10/69
Sir

In compliance with your request, expressed this day, I have the honor of submitting to you a tabulated schedule shewing the number and names of the employees of the botan. Garden, of the Domain, the Govt House Reserve and the scientific branches connected with my establishment, also briefly the position and work allotted to each man in the service and their present remuneration.
The list does not include William Ferguson, whose £250 salary was charged to the Botanic Garden in the March 1870, Estimates (Victoria Parliamentary Paper, 1870 B.—No. 2, p. 12). M had protested against the proposal in M to J. MacPherson, 29 September 1869.

I have also calculated the saving, which might be effected, if after the end of this year only half pay would be given on Saturdays, when the work would cease at noon. In instances of men having large families to support they may additionally be employed for the protection of the general garden and reserves during Saturday and Sunday afternoons, in order that the reduction thus proposed may not fall too heavily on those, who have to provide for many young children. The reduction to be effected by this system of half Saturday's work would be equal to one month's pay in the year to those, who are not on duty. For the attendance at the conservatories, forcing houses and nurseries on Sundays as explained in the schedule, no remuneration is granted, but cottage accommodation provided.

It is scarcely necessary to observe, that the work in a botanic establishment, where besides horticultural skill much other and varied professional knowledge is needed, cannot be easily brought under a strict classification, nor is it possible to define precisely the functions of each man, as according to urgency of circumstances, he may even for protracted periods be needed for any particular work at any special season.

The old rate of wages, which has been but slightly altered of late, was calculated for
ten
hours, but when recently the eight hours system was adopted no reduction was made in consequence of a statement by the late Chief Secretary
JamesMcCulloch:his ministry was replaced by one headed by John MacPherson on 20September 1869, in which McKean was President of the Board of Land and Works and Commissioner of Crown Lands and Survey.
I will need toadd a referencetoHansardwhen I can get it on lineWhen found addalso addnote to 71-04-11.
in Parliament, that the income of none of theGovt employees should be lessened in 1869, because so many losses had been sustained by them during 1868 through deferred payments.

I have also the honor to direct your attention to the circumstance, that no payment is rendered in the Gardens etc. during any ordinary illness, it being understood, that the employees connect themselves with the Friendly Societies, formed for the support of members in times of sickness. The employees are all on weekly warning, and while thus the number may at any time be decreased, it may also happen, that the exigencies of the service may at certain times need additional aid and new engagements. Youths trained here must necessarily advance to positions with better wages, whenever their work merits better remuneration with the increasing age of such youths. All this must render a scale, such as I submit, liable to much fluctuation. Only five holy days are kept in the establishment. At the time, when the reduction of the work hours was discussed, I proposed a system of payment by the hour at fixed rates according to certain positions. A first class gardener might thus obtain at present 1/ p hour laborers 9d p hour, gardenboys 4½p hour, and others according to their different duties various rates ofpay.
M to J. McCulloch, 14 March 1866,contained in a paragraph on 'other reductions, which might be carried out',suggestions concerning the implications of aneight-hourworking day, at the same hourly rates, pointing out that there would be a need to employ extra staff to complete the work. This does not appear to be thepassageto which he is referring here,butno relevant suggestion has been found.
Shouldthis suggestion of mine meet with your approbation, I would work out a schedule, in which every employé here at the time would be enumerated. It may also be advisable to make a small reduction of wages, where good cottage accommodation is given, and the Sunday duties are not heavy or protracted.
I have the honor to be
Sir
your obedient servant
(signed) Ferd. von Mueller
The Honorable J. M'Kean
President of the Board of Land & Works
Schedule of Wages for October

Name of Employé
Not all employees in this list have been fully identified. Those for whom details have been found have entries in the Biographical Register.

cell.p:
Was hitherto employed on the northern Ground now transferred to the Friendly Societies. The discontinuation of his service has been recommended already to the Honble. the President and was already decided on by Mr Grant, although [his]
check ms.
term of service was temporarily prolonged.

div.p: Sundry miscellaneous wages for signwriting, tallies, cutting wood for forcing houses and conservatories, loading manure, carting vegetable mould from Dandenong, blacksmith's jobs, conveyance of teatree for shelter etc.
£9: — prmonth
or £108: — pr annum
Ordinary working expenses (without Smith)

cell.style: border: none; padding-top: 0in; padding-left: 0.0555in; padding-bottom: 0in; padding-right: 0.0555in;

cell.p:
p (26 days)monthincluding £1.f
for?
I can't think of a probable explanatio n
as transcribed , but if as I suspect it is
"I ncluding £1:/ Sunday "
the sum works out correctly , if only one Sunday at £1 is included, so still can't make it reconcile with Groener's Sunday wat ch man, unless it is 5/ per Sunday.
Must see original to get these figures,
Sunday

div.p: This sum is, however, either saved through cases of illness or else recouped by discharging some of the hands at the end of the year
